service.name: Amazon Simple Email Service
service.documentation:
-- | Amazon Simple Email Service (Amazon SES) is a cost-effective outbound-only
-- email-sending service built on the reliable and scalable infrastructure that
-- Amazon.com has developed to serve its own customer base. With Amazon SES, you
-- can send transactional email, marketing messages, or any other type of
-- high-quality content and you only pay for what you use. Along with high
-- deliverability, Amazon SES provides easy, real-time access to your sending
-- statistics and built-in notifications for bounces, complaints, and deliveries
-- to help you fine-tune your email-sending strategy.

cabal.name: Amazon Simple Email Service
cabal.description:
Amazon Simple Email Service (Amazon SES) is a cost-effective outbound-only
email-sending service built on the reliable and scalable infrastructure that
Amazon.com has developed to serve its own customer base. With Amazon SES, you
can send transactional email, marketing messages, or any other type of
high-quality content and you only pay for what you use. Along with high
deliverability, Amazon SES provides easy, real-time access to your sending
statistics and built-in notifications for bounces, complaints, and deliveries
to help you fine-tune your email-sending strategy.

optional.name: _dToAddresses
optional.documentation: -- | The To: field(s) of the message.

optional.name: _dCcAddresses
optional.documentation: -- | The CC: field(s) of the message.

optional.name: _dBccAddresses
optional.documentation: -- | The BCC: field(s) of the message.

fields.documentation: -- | The BCC: field(s) of the message.

fields.documentation: -- | The CC: field(s) of the message.

fields.name: _dToAddresses
fields.documentation: -- | The To: field(s) of the message.

required.name: _idaDkimEnabled
required.documentation:
-- | True if DKIM signing is enabled for email sent from the identity; false
-- otherwise.

required.name: _idaDkimVerificationStatus
required.documentation:
-- | Describes whether Amazon SES has successfully verified the DKIM DNS records
-- (tokens) published in the domain name's DNS. (This only applies to domain
-- identities, not email address identities.)

optional.name: _idaDkimTokens
optional.documentation:
-- | A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. Using these
-- tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public
-- keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that
-- you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72
-- hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign email
-- originating from that domain. (This only applies to domain identities, not
-- email address identities.)
--
-- For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim-dns-records.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _idaDkimEnabled
fields.documentation:
-- | True if DKIM signing is enabled for email sent from the identity; false
-- otherwise.

fields.name: _idaDkimTokens
fields.documentation:
-- | A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. Using these
-- tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public
-- keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that
-- you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72
-- hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign email
-- originating from that domain. (This only applies to domain identities, not
-- email address identities.)
--
-- For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim-dns-records.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _idaDkimVerificationStatus
fields.documentation:
-- | Describes whether Amazon SES has successfully verified the DKIM DNS records
-- (tokens) published in the domain name's DNS. (This only applies to domain
-- identities, not email address identities.)

optional.name: _bText
optional.documentation:
-- | The content of the message, in text format. Use this for text-based email
-- clients, or clients on high-latency networks (such as mobile devices).

optional.name: _bHtml
optional.documentation:
-- | The content of the message, in HTML format. Use this for email clients that
-- can process HTML. You can include clickable links, formatted text, and much
-- more in an HTML message.

fields.name: _bHtml

fields.name: _ivaVerificationToken

required.name: _inaBounceTopic
required.documentation:

-- publish bounce notifications.

required.name: _inaComplaintTopic

required.name: _inaDeliveryTopic
required.documentation:

-- publish delivery notifications.

required.name: _inaForwardingEnabled
required.documentation:
-- | Describes whether Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint notifications
-- as email. 'true' indicates that Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint
-- notifications as email, while 'false' indicates that bounce and complaint
-- notifications will be published only to the specified bounce and complaint
-- Amazon SNS topics.

fields.name: _inaBounceTopic
fields.documentation:

-- publish bounce notifications.

fields.name: _inaComplaintTopic

fields.name: _inaDeliveryTopic

fields.name: _inaForwardingEnabled

-- notifications as email, while 'false' indicates that bounce and complaint
-- notifications will be published only to the specified bounce and complaint
-- Amazon SNS topics.

field.name: _rmData
field.documentation:
-- | The raw data of the message. The client must ensure that the message format
-- complies with Internet email standards regarding email header fields, MIME
-- types, MIME encoding, and base64 encoding (if necessary).
--
-- The To:, CC:, and BCC: headers in the raw message can contain a group list.
--
-- If you are using 'SendRawEmail' with sending authorization, you can include
-- X-headers in the raw message to specify the "Source," "From," and
-- "Return-Path" addresses. For more information, see the documentation for 'SendRawEmail'.
--
-- Do not include these X-headers in the DKIM signature, because they are
-- removed by Amazon SES before sending the email. For more information, go to
-- the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/send-email-raw.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

required.name: _rmData
required.documentation:
-- | The raw data of the message. The client must ensure that the message format
-- complies with Internet email standards regarding email header fields, MIME
-- types, MIME encoding, and base64 encoding (if necessary).
--
-- The To:, CC:, and BCC: headers in the raw message can contain a group list.
--
-- If you are using 'SendRawEmail' with sending authorization, you can include
-- X-headers in the raw message to specify the "Source," "From," and
-- "Return-Path" addresses. For more information, see the documentation for 'SendRawEmail'.
--
-- Do not include these X-headers in the DKIM signature, because they are
-- removed by Amazon SES before sending the email. For more information, go to
-- the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/send-email-raw.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

operations.name: DeleteIdentity
operations.documentation:
-- | Deletes the specified identity (email address or domain) from the list of
-- verified identities.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _diIdentity
field.documentation: -- | The identity to be removed from the list of identities for the AWS Account.

required.name: _diIdentity
required.documentation: -- | The identity to be removed from the list of identities for the AWS Account.

fields.name: _diIdentity
fields.documentation: -- | The identity to be removed from the list of identities for the AWS Account.

operations.name: DeleteIdentityPolicy
operations.documentation:
-- | Deletes the specified sending authorization policy for the given identity
-- (email address or domain). This API returns successfully even if a policy
-- with the specified name does not exist.
--
-- This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the
-- identity, this API will return an error. Sending authorization is a feature
-- that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its
-- identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html AmazonSES Developer Guide>.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

required.name: _dipIdentity
required.documentation:
-- | The identity that is associated with the policy that you want to delete. You
-- can specify the identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource
-- Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

required.name: _dipPolicyName
required.documentation: -- | The name of the policy to be deleted.

fields.name: _dipIdentity
fields.documentation:
-- | The identity that is associated with the policy that you want to delete. You
-- can specify the identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource
-- Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

fields.name: _dipPolicyName
fields.documentation: -- | The name of the policy to be deleted.

operations.name: DeleteVerifiedEmailAddress
operations.documentation:
-- | Deletes the specified email address from the list of verified addresses.
--
-- The DeleteVerifiedEmailAddress action is deprecated as of the May 15, 2012
-- release of Domain Verification. The DeleteIdentity action is now preferred. This action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _dveaEmailAddress
field.documentation: -- | An email address to be removed from the list of verified addresses.

required.name: _dveaEmailAddress
required.documentation: -- | An email address to be removed from the list of verified addresses.

fields.name: _dveaEmailAddress

optional.documentation: -- | The DKIM attributes for an email address or a domain.

fields.name: _gidarDkimAttributes
fields.documentation: -- | The DKIM attributes for an email address or a domain.

operations.name: GetIdentityDkimAttributes
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns the current status of Easy DKIM signing for an entity. For domain
-- name identities, this action also returns the DKIM tokens that are required
-- for Easy DKIM signing, and whether Amazon SES has successfully verified that
-- these tokens have been published.
--
-- This action takes a list of identities as input and returns the following
-- information for each:
--
-- Whether Easy DKIM signing is enabled or disabled. A set of DKIM tokens that
-- represent the identity. If the identity is an email address, the tokens
-- represent the domain of that address. Whether Amazon SES has successfully
-- verified the DKIM tokens published in the domain's DNS. This information is
-- only returned for domain name identities, not for email addresses.  This
-- action is throttled at one request per second and can only get DKIM
-- attributes for up to 100 identities at a time.
--
-- For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim-dns-records.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

field.name: _gidaIdentities
field.documentation: -- | A list of one or more verified identities - email addresses, domains, or both.

optional.name: _gidaIdentities
optional.documentation: -- | A list of one or more verified identities - email addresses, domains, or both.

fields.name: _gidaIdentities
fields.documentation: -- | A list of one or more verified identities - email addresses, domains, or both.

field.name: _ginarNotificationAttributes
field.documentation: -- | A map of Identity to IdentityNotificationAttributes.

optional.name: _ginarNotificationAttributes
optional.documentation: -- | A map of Identity to IdentityNotificationAttributes.

fields.name: _ginarNotificationAttributes
fields.documentation: -- | A map of Identity to IdentityNotificationAttributes.

operations.name: GetIdentityNotificationAttributes
operations.documentation:
-- | Given a list of verified identities (email addresses and/or domains), returns
-- a structure describing identity notification attributes.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second and can only get
-- notification attributes for up to 100 identities at a time.
--
-- For more information about using notifications with Amazon SES, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/notifications.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

field.name: _ginaIdentities
field.documentation:
-- | A list of one or more identities. You can specify an identity by using its
-- name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.

optional.name: _ginaIdentities
optional.documentation:
-- | A list of one or more identities. You can specify an identity by using its
-- name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.

fields.name: _ginaIdentities
fields.documentation:
-- | A list of one or more identities. You can specify an identity by using its
-- name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.

field.name: _giprPolicies
field.documentation: -- | A map of policy names to policies.

optional.name: _giprPolicies
optional.documentation: -- | A map of policy names to policies.

fields.name: _giprPolicies
fields.documentation: -- | A map of policy names to policies.

operations.name: GetIdentityPolicies
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns the requested sending authorization policies for the given identity
-- (email address or domain). The policies are returned as a map of policy names
-- to policy contents. You can retrieve a maximum of 20 policies at a time.
--
-- This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the
-- identity, this API will return an error. Sending authorization is a feature
-- that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its
-- identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html AmazonSES Developer Guide>.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

required.name: _gipIdentity
required.documentation:
-- | The identity for which the policies will be retrieved. You can specify an
-- identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
-- Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

optional.name: _gipPolicyNames
optional.documentation:
-- | A list of the names of policies to be retrieved. You can retrieve a maximum
-- of 20 policies at a time. If you do not know the names of the policies that
-- are attached to the identity, you can use 'ListIdentityPolicies'.

fields.name: _gipIdentity
fields.documentation:
-- | The identity for which the policies will be retrieved. You can specify an
-- identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
-- Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

fields.name: _gipPolicyNames
fields.documentation:
-- | A list of the names of policies to be retrieved. You can retrieve a maximum
-- of 20 policies at a time. If you do not know the names of the policies that
-- are attached to the identity, you can use 'ListIdentityPolicies'.

field.name: _givarVerificationAttributes
field.documentation: -- | A map of Identities to IdentityVerificationAttributes objects.

optional.name: _givarVerificationAttributes
optional.documentation: -- | A map of Identities to IdentityVerificationAttributes objects.

fields.name: _givarVerificationAttributes
fields.documentation: -- | A map of Identities to IdentityVerificationAttributes objects.

operations.name: GetIdentityVerificationAttributes
operations.documentation:
-- | Given a list of identities (email addresses and/or domains), returns the
-- verification status and (for domain identities) the verification token for
-- each identity.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second and can only get
-- verification attributes for up to 100 identities at a time.

field.name: _givaIdentities
field.documentation: -- | A list of identities.

optional.name: _givaIdentities
optional.documentation: -- | A list of identities.

fields.name: _givaIdentities
fields.documentation: -- | A list of identities.

optional.name: _gsqrMax24HourSend
optional.documentation:
-- | The maximum number of emails the user is allowed to send in a 24-hour
-- interval. A value of -1 signifies an unlimited quota.

optional.name: _gsqrMaxSendRate
optional.documentation:
-- | The maximum number of emails that Amazon SES can accept from the user's
-- account per second.
--
-- The rate at which Amazon SES accepts the user's messages might be less than
-- the maximum send rate.

optional.name: _gsqrSentLast24Hours
optional.documentation: -- | The number of emails sent during the previous 24 hours.

fields.name: _gsqrMax24HourSend
fields.documentation:
-- | The maximum number of emails the user is allowed to send in a 24-hour
-- interval. A value of -1 signifies an unlimited quota.

fields.name: _gsqrMaxSendRate
fields.documentation:
-- | The maximum number of emails that Amazon SES can accept from the user's
-- account per second.
--
-- The rate at which Amazon SES accepts the user's messages might be less than
-- the maximum send rate.

fields.name: _gsqrSentLast24Hours
fields.documentation: -- | The number of emails sent during the previous 24 hours.

operations.name: GetSendQuota
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns the user's current sending limits.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _gssrSendDataPoints
field.documentation: -- | A list of data points, each of which represents 15 minutes of activity.

optional.name: _gssrSendDataPoints
optional.documentation: -- | A list of data points, each of which represents 15 minutes of activity.

fields.name: _gssrSendDataPoints
fields.documentation: -- | A list of data points, each of which represents 15 minutes of activity.

operations.name: GetSendStatistics
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns the user's sending statistics. The result is a list of data points,
-- representing the last two weeks of sending activity.
--
-- Each data point in the list contains statistics for a 15-minute interval.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

optional.name: _lirIdentities
optional.documentation: -- | A list of identities.

optional.name: _lirNextToken
optional.documentation: -- | The token used for pagination.

fields.name: _lirIdentities
fields.documentation: -- | A list of identities.

fields.name: _lirNextToken
fields.documentation: -- | The token used for pagination.

operations.name: ListIdentities
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns a list containing all of the identities (email addresses and domains)
-- for a specific AWS Account, regardless of verification status.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

optional.name: _liIdentityType
optional.documentation:
-- | The type of the identities to list. Possible values are "EmailAddress" and
-- "Domain". If this parameter is omitted, then all identities will be listed.

optional.name: _liNextToken
optional.documentation: -- | The token to use for pagination.

optional.name: _liMaxItems
optional.documentation:
-- | The maximum number of identities per page. Possible values are 1-1000
-- inclusive.

fields.name: _liIdentityType
fields.documentation:
-- | The type of the identities to list. Possible values are "EmailAddress" and
-- "Domain". If this parameter is omitted, then all identities will be listed.

fields.name: _liMaxItems
fields.documentation:
-- | The maximum number of identities per page. Possible values are 1-1000
-- inclusive.

fields.name: _liNextToken
fields.documentation: -- | The token to use for pagination.

field.name: _liprPolicyNames
field.documentation: -- | A list of names of policies that apply to the specified identity.

optional.name: _liprPolicyNames
optional.documentation: -- | A list of names of policies that apply to the specified identity.

fields.name: _liprPolicyNames
fields.documentation: -- | A list of names of policies that apply to the specified identity.

operations.name: ListIdentityPolicies
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns a list of sending authorization policies that are attached to the
-- given identity (email address or domain). This API returns only a list. If
-- you want the actual policy content, you can use 'GetIdentityPolicies'.
--
-- This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the
-- identity, this API will return an error. Sending authorization is a feature
-- that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its
-- identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html AmazonSES Developer Guide>.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _lipIdentity
field.documentation:
-- | The identity that is associated with the policy for which the policies will
-- be listed. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its
-- Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

required.name: _lipIdentity
required.documentation:
-- | The identity that is associated with the policy for which the policies will
-- be listed. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its
-- Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

fields.name: _lipIdentity
fields.documentation:
-- | The identity that is associated with the policy for which the policies will
-- be listed. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its
-- Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

field.name: _lvearVerifiedEmailAddresses
field.documentation: -- | A list of email addresses that have been verified.

optional.name: _lvearVerifiedEmailAddresses
optional.documentation: -- | A list of email addresses that have been verified.

fields.name: _lvearVerifiedEmailAddresses
fields.documentation: -- | A list of email addresses that have been verified.

operations.name: ListVerifiedEmailAddresses
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns a list containing all of the email addresses that have been verified.
--
-- The ListVerifiedEmailAddresses action is deprecated as of the May 15, 2012
-- release of Domain Verification. The ListIdentities action is now preferred. This action is throttled at one request per second.

operations.name: PutIdentityPolicy
operations.documentation:
-- | Adds or updates a sending authorization policy for the specified identity
-- (email address or domain).
--
-- This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the
-- identity, this API will return an error. Sending authorization is a feature
-- that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its
-- identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html AmazonSES Developer Guide>.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.

required.name: _pipIdentity
required.documentation:
-- | The identity to which the policy will apply. You can specify an identity by
-- using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

required.name: _pipPolicyName
required.documentation:
-- | The name of the policy.
--
-- The policy name cannot exceed 64 characters and can only include
-- alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores.

required.name: _pipPolicy
required.documentation:
-- | The text of the policy in JSON format. The policy cannot exceed 4 KB.
--
-- For information about the syntax of sending authorization policies, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-policies.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _pipIdentity
fields.documentation:
-- | The identity to which the policy will apply. You can specify an identity by
-- using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.
--
-- To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

fields.name: _pipPolicy
fields.documentation:
-- | The text of the policy in JSON format. The policy cannot exceed 4 KB.
--
-- For information about the syntax of sending authorization policies, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-policies.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _pipPolicyName
fields.documentation:
-- | The name of the policy.
--
-- The policy name cannot exceed 64 characters and can only include
-- alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores.

field.name: _serMessageId
field.documentation: -- | The unique message identifier returned from the 'SendEmail' action.

required.name: _serMessageId
required.documentation: -- | The unique message identifier returned from the 'SendEmail' action.

fields.name: _serMessageId
fields.documentation: -- | The unique message identifier returned from the 'SendEmail' action.

operations.name: SendEmail
operations.documentation:
-- | Composes an email message based on input data, and then immediately queues
-- the message for sending.
--
-- There are several important points to know about 'SendEmail':
--
-- You can only send email from verified email addresses and domains;
-- otherwise, you will get an "Email address not verified" error. If your
-- account is still in the Amazon SES sandbox, you must also verify every
-- recipient email address except for the recipients provided by the Amazon SES
-- mailbox simulator. For more information, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/verify-addresses-and-domains.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.
-- The total size of the message cannot exceed 10 MB. This includes any
-- attachments that are part of the message. Amazon SES has a limit on the total
-- number of recipients per message. The combined number of To:, CC: and BCC:
-- email addresses cannot exceed 50. If you need to send an email message to a
-- larger audience, you can divide your recipient list into groups of 50 or
-- fewer, and then call Amazon SES repeatedly to send the message to each group.
-- For every message that you send, the total number of recipients (To:, CC: and
-- BCC:) is counted against your sending quota - the maximum number of emails
-- you can send in a 24-hour period. For information about your sending quota,
-- go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/manage-sending-limits.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

required.name: _seSource
required.documentation:
-- | The email address that is sending the email. This email address must be
-- either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that has been
-- verified with Amazon SES. For information about verifying identities, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/verify-addresses-and-domains.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.
--
-- If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted to do
-- so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify the 'SourceArn'
-- parameter. For more information about sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html AmazonSES Developer Guide>.
--
-- In all cases, the email address must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must
-- contain any other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC
-- 2047) instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the
-- following form: '=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?='. For more information, see <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2047 RFC 2047>.

required.name: _seDestination
required.documentation: -- | The destination for this email, composed of To:, CC:, and BCC: fields.

required.name: _seMessage
required.documentation: -- | The message to be sent.

optional.name: _seReplyToAddresses
optional.documentation:
-- | The reply-to email address(es) for the message. If the recipient replies to
-- the message, each reply-to address will receive the reply.

optional.name: _seReturnPath
optional.documentation:
-- | The email address to which bounces and complaints are to be forwarded when
-- feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be delivered to the
-- recipient, then an error message will be returned from the recipient's ISP;
-- this message will then be forwarded to the email address specified by the 'ReturnPath' parameter. The 'ReturnPath' parameter is never overwritten. This email address
-- must be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that
-- has been verified with Amazon SES.

optional.name: _seSourceArn
optional.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to send for the email address specified in the 'Source' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from 'user@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'SourceArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'Source' to be 'user@example.com'.
--
-- For more information about sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html Amazon SESDeveloper Guide>.

optional.name: _seReturnPathArn
optional.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to use the email address specified in the 'ReturnPath' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use 'feedback@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'ReturnPathArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'ReturnPath' to be 'feedback@example.com'.
--
-- For more information about sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html Amazon SESDeveloper Guide>.

fields.name: _seDestination
fields.documentation: -- | The destination for this email, composed of To:, CC:, and BCC: fields.

fields.name: _seMessage
fields.documentation: -- | The message to be sent.

fields.name: _seReplyToAddresses
fields.documentation:
-- | The reply-to email address(es) for the message. If the recipient replies to
-- the message, each reply-to address will receive the reply.

fields.name: _seReturnPath
fields.documentation:
-- | The email address to which bounces and complaints are to be forwarded when
-- feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be delivered to the
-- recipient, then an error message will be returned from the recipient's ISP;
-- this message will then be forwarded to the email address specified by the 'ReturnPath' parameter. The 'ReturnPath' parameter is never overwritten. This email address
-- must be either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that
-- has been verified with Amazon SES.

fields.name: _seReturnPathArn
fields.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to use the email address specified in the 'ReturnPath' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use 'feedback@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'ReturnPathArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'ReturnPath' to be 'feedback@example.com'.
--
-- For more information about sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html Amazon SESDeveloper Guide>.

fields.name: _seSource
fields.documentation:
-- | The email address that is sending the email. This email address must be
-- either individually verified with Amazon SES, or from a domain that has been
-- verified with Amazon SES. For information about verifying identities, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/verify-addresses-and-domains.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.
--
-- If you are sending on behalf of another user and have been permitted to do
-- so by a sending authorization policy, then you must also specify the 'SourceArn'
-- parameter. For more information about sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html AmazonSES Developer Guide>.
--
-- In all cases, the email address must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must
-- contain any other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC
-- 2047) instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the
-- following form: '=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?='. For more information, see <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2047 RFC 2047>.

fields.name: _seSourceArn
fields.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to send for the email address specified in the 'Source' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from 'user@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'SourceArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'Source' to be 'user@example.com'.
--
-- For more information about sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html Amazon SESDeveloper Guide>.

field.name: _srerMessageId
field.documentation: -- | The unique message identifier returned from the 'SendRawEmail' action.

required.name: _srerMessageId
required.documentation: -- | The unique message identifier returned from the 'SendRawEmail' action.

fields.name: _srerMessageId
fields.documentation: -- | The unique message identifier returned from the 'SendRawEmail' action.

operations.name: SendRawEmail
operations.documentation:
-- | Sends an email message, with header and content specified by the client. The 'SendRawEmail' action is useful for sending multipart MIME emails. The raw text of the
-- message must comply with Internet email standards; otherwise, the message
-- cannot be sent.
--
-- There are several important points to know about 'SendRawEmail':
--
-- You can only send email from verified email addresses and domains;
-- otherwise, you will get an "Email address not verified" error. If your
-- account is still in the Amazon SES sandbox, you must also verify every
-- recipient email address except for the recipients provided by the Amazon SES
-- mailbox simulator. For more information, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/verify-addresses-and-domains.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.
-- The total size of the message cannot exceed 10 MB. This includes any
-- attachments that are part of the message. Amazon SES has a limit on the total
-- number of recipients per message. The combined number of To:, CC: and BCC:
-- email addresses cannot exceed 50. If you need to send an email message to a
-- larger audience, you can divide your recipient list into groups of 50 or
-- fewer, and then call Amazon SES repeatedly to send the message to each group.
-- The To:, CC:, and BCC: headers in the raw message can contain a group list.
-- Note that each recipient in a group list counts towards the 50-recipient
-- limit. For every message that you send, the total number of recipients (To:,
-- CC: and BCC:) is counted against your sending quota - the maximum number of
-- emails you can send in a 24-hour period. For information about your sending
-- quota, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/manage-sending-limits.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>. If you are using sending
-- authorization to send on behalf of another user, 'SendRawEmail' enables you to
-- specify the cross-account identity for the email's "Source," "From," and
-- "Return-Path" parameters in one of two ways: you can pass optional parameters 'SourceArn', 'FromArn', and/or 'ReturnPathArn' to the API, or you can include the
-- following X-headers in the header of your raw email:  'X-SES-SOURCE-ARN' 'X-SES-FROM-ARN' 'X-SES-RETURN-PATH-ARN'  Do not include these X-headers in the DKIM signature,
-- because they are removed by Amazon SES before sending the email. For the most
-- common sending authorization use case, we recommend that you specify the 'SourceIdentityArn' and do not specify either the 'FromIdentityArn' or 'ReturnPathIdentityArn'. (The
-- same note applies to the corresponding X-headers.) If you only specify the 'SourceIdentityArn', Amazon SES will simply set the "From" address and the "Return Path" address
-- to the identity specified in 'SourceIdentityArn'. For more information about
-- sending authorization, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

required.name: _sreRawMessage
required.documentation:
-- | The raw text of the message. The client is responsible for ensuring the
-- following:
--
-- Message must contain a header and a body, separated by a blank line. All
-- required header fields must be present. Each part of a multipart MIME message
-- must be formatted properly. MIME content types must be among those supported
-- by Amazon SES. For more information, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/mime-types.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.  Content must be base64-encoded, if MIME requires it.
--

optional.name: _sreSource
optional.documentation:
-- | The identity's email address. If you do not provide a value for this
-- parameter, you must specify a "From" address in the raw text of the message.
-- (You can also specify both.)
--
-- By default, the string must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must contain any
-- other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC 2047)
-- instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following
-- form: '=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?='. For more information, see <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2047 RFC 2047>.
--
-- If you specify the 'Source' parameter and have feedback forwarding enabled,
-- then bounces and complaints will be sent to this email address. This takes
-- precedence over any /Return-Path/ header that you might include in the raw text
-- of the message.

optional.name: _sreDestinations
optional.documentation:
-- | A list of destinations for the message, consisting of To:, CC:, and BCC:
-- addresses.

optional.name: _sreFromArn
optional.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to specify a particular "From" address in the header of the raw
-- email.
--
-- Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header 'X-SES-FROM-ARN' in
-- the raw message of the email. If you use both the 'FromArn' parameter and the
-- corresponding X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the 'FromArn' parameter.
--
-- For information about when to use this parameter, see the description of 'SendRawEmail' in this guide, or see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-delegate-sender-tasks-email.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

optional.name: _sreSourceArn
optional.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to send for the email address specified in the 'Source' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from 'user@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'SourceArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'Source' to be 'user@example.com'.
--
-- Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header 'X-SES-SOURCE-ARN'
-- in the raw message of the email. If you use both the 'SourceArn' parameter and
-- the corresponding X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the 'SourceArn'
-- parameter.
--
-- For information about when to use this parameter, see the description of 'SendRawEmail' in this guide, or see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-delegate-sender-tasks-email.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

optional.name: _sreReturnPathArn
optional.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to use the email address specified in the 'ReturnPath' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use 'feedback@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'ReturnPathArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'ReturnPath' to be 'feedback@example.com'.
--
-- Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header 'X-SES-RETURN-PATH-ARN' in the raw message of the email. If you use both the 'ReturnPathArn' parameter
-- and the corresponding X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the 'ReturnPathArn'
-- parameter.
--
-- For information about when to use this parameter, see the description of 'SendRawEmail' in this guide, or see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-delegate-sender-tasks-email.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _sreDestinations
fields.documentation:
-- | A list of destinations for the message, consisting of To:, CC:, and BCC:
-- addresses.

fields.name: _sreFromArn
fields.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to specify a particular "From" address in the header of the raw
-- email.
--
-- Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header 'X-SES-FROM-ARN' in
-- the raw message of the email. If you use both the 'FromArn' parameter and the
-- corresponding X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the 'FromArn' parameter.
--
-- For information about when to use this parameter, see the description of 'SendRawEmail' in this guide, or see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-delegate-sender-tasks-email.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _sreRawMessage
fields.documentation:
-- | The raw text of the message. The client is responsible for ensuring the
-- following:
--
-- Message must contain a header and a body, separated by a blank line. All
-- required header fields must be present. Each part of a multipart MIME message
-- must be formatted properly. MIME content types must be among those supported
-- by Amazon SES. For more information, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/mime-types.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.  Content must be base64-encoded, if MIME requires it.
--

fields.name: _sreReturnPathArn
fields.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to use the email address specified in the 'ReturnPath' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to use 'feedback@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'ReturnPathArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'ReturnPath' to be 'feedback@example.com'.
--
-- Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header 'X-SES-RETURN-PATH-ARN' in the raw message of the email. If you use both the 'ReturnPathArn' parameter
-- and the corresponding X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the 'ReturnPathArn'
-- parameter.
--
-- For information about when to use this parameter, see the description of 'SendRawEmail' in this guide, or see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-delegate-sender-tasks-email.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _sreSource
fields.documentation:
-- | The identity's email address. If you do not provide a value for this
-- parameter, you must specify a "From" address in the raw text of the message.
-- (You can also specify both.)
--
-- By default, the string must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must contain any
-- other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC 2047)
-- instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following
-- form: '=?charset?encoding?encoded-text?='. For more information, see <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2047 RFC 2047>.
--
-- If you specify the 'Source' parameter and have feedback forwarding enabled,
-- then bounces and complaints will be sent to this email address. This takes
-- precedence over any /Return-Path/ header that you might include in the raw text
-- of the message.

fields.name: _sreSourceArn
fields.documentation:
-- | This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the
-- identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that
-- permits you to send for the email address specified in the 'Source' parameter.
--
-- For example, if the owner of 'example.com' (which has ARN 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com') attaches a policy to it that authorizes you to send from 'user@example.com',
-- then you would specify the 'SourceArn' to be 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com', and the 'Source' to be 'user@example.com'.
--
-- Instead of using this parameter, you can use the X-header 'X-SES-SOURCE-ARN'
-- in the raw message of the email. If you use both the 'SourceArn' parameter and
-- the corresponding X-header, Amazon SES uses the value of the 'SourceArn'
-- parameter.
--
-- For information about when to use this parameter, see the description of 'SendRawEmail' in this guide, or see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-delegate-sender-tasks-email.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

operations.name: SetIdentityDkimEnabled
operations.documentation:
-- | Enables or disables Easy DKIM signing of email sent from an identity:
--
-- If Easy DKIM signing is enabled for a domain name identity (e.g., 'example.com'), then Amazon SES will DKIM-sign all email sent by addresses under that
-- domain name (e.g., 'user@example.com'). If Easy DKIM signing is enabled for an
-- email address, then Amazon SES will DKIM-sign all email sent by that email
-- address.  For email addresses (e.g., 'user@example.com'), you can only enable
-- Easy DKIM signing if the corresponding domain (e.g., 'example.com') has been
-- set up for Easy DKIM using the AWS Console or the 'VerifyDomainDkim' action.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.
--
-- For more information about Easy DKIM signing, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim.html Amazon SES DeveloperGuide>.

required.name: _sideIdentity
required.documentation: -- | The identity for which DKIM signing should be enabled or disabled.

required.name: _sideDkimEnabled
required.documentation:
-- | Sets whether DKIM signing is enabled for an identity. Set to 'true' to enable
-- DKIM signing for this identity; 'false' to disable it.

fields.name: _sideDkimEnabled
fields.documentation:
-- | Sets whether DKIM signing is enabled for an identity. Set to 'true' to enable
-- DKIM signing for this identity; 'false' to disable it.

fields.name: _sideIdentity
fields.documentation: -- | The identity for which DKIM signing should be enabled or disabled.

operations.name: SetIdentityFeedbackForwardingEnabled
operations.documentation:
-- | Given an identity (email address or domain), enables or disables whether
-- Amazon SES forwards bounce and complaint notifications as email. Feedback
-- forwarding can only be disabled when Amazon Simple Notification Service
-- (Amazon SNS) topics are specified for both bounces and complaints.
--
-- Feedback forwarding does not apply to delivery notifications. Delivery
-- notifications are only available through Amazon SNS. This action is throttled
-- at one request per second.
--
-- For more information about using notifications with Amazon SES, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/notifications.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

required.name: _siffeIdentity
required.documentation:
-- | The identity for which to set bounce and complaint notification forwarding.
-- Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com'.

required.name: _siffeForwardingEnabled
required.documentation:
-- | Sets whether Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint notifications as
-- email. 'true' specifies that Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint
-- notifications as email, in addition to any Amazon SNS topic publishing
-- otherwise specified. 'false' specifies that Amazon SES will publish bounce and
-- complaint notifications only through Amazon SNS. This value can only be set
-- to 'false' when Amazon SNS topics are set for both 'Bounce' and 'Complaint'
-- notification types.

fields.name: _siffeForwardingEnabled
fields.documentation:
-- | Sets whether Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint notifications as
-- email. 'true' specifies that Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint
-- notifications as email, in addition to any Amazon SNS topic publishing
-- otherwise specified. 'false' specifies that Amazon SES will publish bounce and
-- complaint notifications only through Amazon SNS. This value can only be set
-- to 'false' when Amazon SNS topics are set for both 'Bounce' and 'Complaint'
-- notification types.

fields.name: _siffeIdentity
fields.documentation:
-- | The identity for which to set bounce and complaint notification forwarding.
-- Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com'.

operations.name: SetIdentityNotificationTopic
operations.documentation:
-- | Given an identity (email address or domain), sets the Amazon Simple
-- Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic to which Amazon SES will publish
-- bounce, complaint, and/or delivery notifications for emails sent with that
-- identity as the 'Source'.
--
-- Unless feedback forwarding is enabled, you must specify Amazon SNS topics
-- for bounce and complaint notifications. For more information, see 'SetIdentityFeedbackForwardingEnabled'.  This action is throttled at one request per second.
--
-- For more information about feedback notification, see the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/notifications.html Amazon SESDeveloper Guide>.

required.name: _sintIdentity
required.documentation:
-- | The identity for which the Amazon SNS topic will be set. You can specify an
-- identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
-- Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.

required.name: _sintNotificationType
required.documentation:
-- | The type of notifications that will be published to the specified Amazon SNS
-- topic.

optional.name: _sintSnsTopic
optional.documentation:
-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic. If the parameter is
-- omitted from the request or a null value is passed, 'SnsTopic' is cleared and
-- publishing is disabled.

fields.name: _sintIdentity
fields.documentation:
-- | The identity for which the Amazon SNS topic will be set. You can specify an
-- identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
-- Examples: 'user@example.com', 'example.com', 'arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com'.

fields.name: _sintNotificationType
fields.documentation:
-- | The type of notifications that will be published to the specified Amazon SNS
-- topic.

fields.name: _sintSnsTopic
fields.documentation:
-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic. If the parameter is
-- omitted from the request or a null value is passed, 'SnsTopic' is cleared and
-- publishing is disabled.

field.name: _vddrDkimTokens
field.documentation:
-- | A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. If the
-- identity is an email address, the tokens represent the domain of that address.
--
-- Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to
-- DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually
-- detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may
-- take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to
-- DKIM-sign emails originating from that domain.
--
-- For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim-dns-records.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

optional.name: _vddrDkimTokens
optional.documentation:
-- | A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. If the
-- identity is an email address, the tokens represent the domain of that address.
--
-- Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to
-- DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually
-- detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may
-- take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to
-- DKIM-sign emails originating from that domain.
--
-- For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim-dns-records.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

fields.name: _vddrDkimTokens
fields.documentation:
-- | A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. If the
-- identity is an email address, the tokens represent the domain of that address.
--
-- Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to
-- DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually
-- detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may
-- take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to
-- DKIM-sign emails originating from that domain.
--
-- For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim-dns-records.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

operations.name: VerifyDomainDkim
operations.documentation:
-- | Returns a set of DKIM tokens for a domain. DKIM /tokens/ are character strings
-- that represent your domain's identity. Using these tokens, you will need to
-- create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES.
-- Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that you have updated your DNS
-- records; this detection process may take up to 72 hours. Upon successful
-- detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign email originating from that
-- domain.
--
-- This action is throttled at one request per second.
--
-- To enable or disable Easy DKIM signing for a domain, use the 'SetIdentityDkimEnabled' action.
--
-- For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/easy-dkim-dns-records.html Amazon SES Developer Guide>.

field.name: _vddDomain
field.documentation: -- | The name of the domain to be verified for Easy DKIM signing.

required.name: _vddDomain
required.documentation: -- | The name of the domain to be verified for Easy DKIM signing.

fields.name: _vddDomain
fields.documentation: -- | The name of the domain to be verified for Easy DKIM signing.

field.name: _vdirVerificationToken
field.documentation:
-- | A TXT record that must be placed in the DNS settings for the domain, in order
-- to complete domain verification.

required.name: _vdirVerificationToken
required.documentation:
-- | A TXT record that must be placed in the DNS settings for the domain, in order
-- to complete domain verification.

fields.name: _vdirVerificationToken
fields.documentation:
-- | A TXT record that must be placed in the DNS settings for the domain, in order
-- to complete domain verification.

operations.name: VerifyEmailAddress
operations.documentation:
-- | Verifies an email address. This action causes a confirmation email message to
-- be sent to the specified address.
--
-- The VerifyEmailAddress action is deprecated as of the May 15, 2012 release
-- of Domain Verification. The VerifyEmailIdentity action is now preferred. This
-- action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _veaEmailAddress
field.documentation: -- | The email address to be verified.

required.name: _veaEmailAddress
required.documentation: -- | The email address to be verified.

fields.name: _veaEmailAddress
